measured_by: Proportion of choices congruent with pre-choice value ratings
justification: The article defines consistency as choices that are congruent with preferences inferred from pre-choice value ratings and assesses its relationship with value differences (dVa and dVb).
Participants provided their subjective measure of choice confidence using a horizontal slider scale, indicating their degree of certainty about their choice.

measured_by: Time taken to make a choice
justification: The time taken by participants to respond during choice tasks was recorded and analyzed to determine its relationship with value differences and other factors.
Participants used a horizontal slider scale to indicate the extent to which they thought about each choice, providing a subjective measure of mental effort expenditure.

The article measures value refinement by calculating the post-choice minus pre-choice value difference for the chosen option versus the average of both unchosen options, reflecting changes in value estimates after deliberation.
Participants rated their subjective desirability of snack items on a horizontal slider scale, providing initial value estimates for each option.

measured_by: Symmetrical bar adjustment around the slider cursor
justification: Participants adjusted a symmetrical solid bar around the cursor of the slider scale to indicate their uncertainty about the value ratings they provided.

measured_by: Impact on choice behavior and post-choice dynamics
justification: The study examines how subjective feelings of certainty about value estimates influence choice behavior and subsequent value changes, measuring these impacts through regression analyses.
